subject: Re: [junit] which jdk will work with JUnit on Redhat6.2?
msgSnippet: I don t think that any of these are the problem.  My RH6.2 is out of the box, meaning the original glibc and original X11 and runs on a laptop. I ve tried two
messageBody:
I don't think that any of these are the problem. My RH6.2 is out of the
box, meaning the original glibc and original X11 and runs on a laptop. I've
tried two jdk1.2.2s, blackdown's and sun's and both have the same problems.

What version of JUnit are you using?


----- Original Message -----
From: "Joi Ellis" <joi@...>
To: <junit@egroups.com>
Sent: Friday, January 19, 2001 1:36 PM
Subject: Re: [junit] which jdk will work with JUnit on Redhat6.2?


> On Fri, 19 Jan 2001, Peter Bismuti wrote:
>
> >
> > I've been told my JDK is broken (see output below). I've had problems
in the past, for example on 2 different JDKs jar files could not be added to
my classpath. I use Redhat6.2, is there anyone who knows of a JDK that will
work with with JUnit?
>
> I have run Red Hat 6.2, and I regularly use JUnit with Sun's JDK 1.2.2,
> and with Sun's JDK 1.3, and occasionally with Blackdown 1.3 rc1 and
> IBM 1.3.
>
> Things to watch for:
>
> Running SMP kernels with JDKs which don't support SMP. So far, I believe
> only Sun 1.3 and Blackdown 1.3rc1 support SMP. IBM 1.3, and Sun 1.2.2
> do NOT.
>
> Glibc versions. RH 6.2's default glibcs should be okay with Sun and IBM.
> If you've upgraded them to match RH7.0's glibcs, you need to rip that out
> and reinstall good ones: RH7's glibcs are broken. Either put 6.2's back
in,
> or download the most recent glibcs for RH7.0. There have been at least 3
> different upgrades for those since 7.0 came out.
>
> X11 version. There is a minimum XFree86 version required for Java.
> See the release notes/install docs for the JVM you're using for details.
> This item tends to show up from time to time, but not nearly as often
> as the first two.
>
> --
> Joi Ellis Software Engineer
> Aravox Technologies joi@..., gyles19@...
>
> No matter what we think of Linux versus FreeBSD, etc., the one thing I
> really like about Linux is that it has Microsoft worried. Anything
> that kicks a monopoly in the pants has got to be good for something.
> - Chris Johnson
>
>

>
